item.title: To Have Machines Make Math Proofs, Turn Them Into a Puzzle
item.dc:creator: John Pavlus
item.description:
Marijn Heule turns mathematical statements into something like Sudoku puzzles, then has computers go to work on them. His proofs have been called “disgusting,” but they go beyond what any human can do.

The post To Have Machines Make Math Proofs, Turn Them Into a Puzzle first appeared on Quanta Magazine
item.content:encoded:
The mathematical conundrums that Marijn Heule has helped crack in the last decade sound like code names lifted from a sci-fi spy novel: the empty hexagon. Schur Number 5. Keller’s conjecture, dimension seven. In reality, they are (or, more accurately, were) some of the most stubborn problems in geometry and combinatorics, defying solution for 90 years or more. item.title: Physicists Take the Imaginary Numbers Out of Quantum Mechanics
item.dc:creator: Daniel Garisto
item.description:
Quantum mechanics has at last been formulated exclusively with real numbers, bringing a mathematical puzzle at the heart of the theory into a new era of inquiry.

The post Physicists Take the Imaginary Numbers Out of Quantum Mechanics first appeared on Quanta Magazine
item.content:encoded:
A century ago, the strange behavior of atoms and elementary particles led physicists to formulate a new theory of nature. That theory, quantum mechanics, found immediate success, proving its worth with accurate calculations of hydrogen’s emission and absorption of light. There was, however, a snag. The central equation of quantum mechanics featured the imaginary number i, the square root of −1.

item.title: How Your Brain Creates ‘Aha’ Moments and Why They Stick
item.dc:creator: Nora Bradford
item.description:
A sudden flash of insight is a product of your brain. Neuroscientists track the neural activity underlying an “aha” and how it might boost memory.

item.content:encoded:
Here are three words: pine, crab, sauce. There’s a fourth word that combines with each of the others to create another common word. What is it? When the answer finally comes to you, it’ll likely feel instantaneous. item.description:
In the mid-19th century, Bernhard Riemann conceived of a new way to think about mathematical spaces, providing the foundation for modern geometry and physics.

item.content:encoded:
